abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation
            Sector Project's outcome is rated as highly
            satisfactory. The lessons drawn from this project include:
            1) The Argentine experience confirmed that strong government
            ownership and commitment can help bring about dramatic and
            positive changes in highway sector policies within a
            relatively short period of time. 2) This project has also
            shown that the implementation of an optimized network
            rehabilitation and maintenance strategy can effectively
            bring an entire road network back into a satisfactory
            condition over a period of a few years and at a reasonable
            cost. 3) Proactive supervision and restructuring of the
            project as soon as critical assumptions have changed were
            essential to achieve the development objective: in this
            case, by the end of 1995, stock of subprojects ready for
            bidding was lacking and the design and adoption of the CREMA
            (Contract of Rehabilitation and Maintenance) system proved
            to be an appropriate solution for facilitating the use of
            the Bank loan. 4) Good quality of project design at entry,
            full Borrower's commitment and innovativeness, sound
            highway maintenance policies involving private sector
            participation, Bank flexibility in revising the Loan
            Agreement, as well as good support to supervision missions
            from decentralized Country Management Unit are factors that
            played a vital role in bringing about the success of the project.
